question: Will ChatGPT be able to order you a Starbucks delivery in Q1 2025?
description: In a January 2025 [blog post](https://blog.samaltman.com/reflections), OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said, "We are now confident we know how to build AGI as we have traditionally understood it. We believe that, in 2025, we may see the first AI agents 'join the workforce' and materially change the output of companies. We continue to believe that iteratively putting great tools in the hands of people leads to great, broadly-distributed outcomes."
fine_print: ChatGPT should be able to successfully submit a Starbucks delivery order to a semi-arbitrary address in North America after a user has provided the order information. We define “semi-arbitrary” as substantially similar to anywhere that Starbucks (through its current partner DoorDash) is able to deliver normally when an order is placed through the Starbucks app or website. The LLM must generally be able to order any item available for delivery on the menu. Being limited to only ordering the user's most recent order or a subset of items is not sufficient. A user must be able to request the order solely through the main chat input field on the main chat interface. If additional plugins, API or other tools are required, it will not count.
news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**2025 and AI: Technological Breakthrough or Insurmountable Challenge?**
Artificial intelligence is revolutionizing the world at an impressive speed, and 2025 is expected to be a crucial year in understanding where this transformation will lead. In recent years, we have witnessed a technological boom: tools like ChatGPT have conquered millions of users in a short time, demonstrating how AI can enter our daily lives. However, this technology also brings important challenges, especially when it comes to security and environmental impact. One of the most discussed problems is the energy consumption. AI does not work in a vacuum: behind every command, every generated response, there are enormous data centers that work non-stop and require an increasingly large amount of electricity. In the last ten years, the number of these centers has doubled, and if the trend continues, they will soon consume as much as entire nations. Therefore, companies are looking for solutions to make these systems more efficient and less energy-intensive. Some are focusing on technologies that optimize consumption, while others are looking at alternative energy sources. There are even those who are investing in nuclear energy to power data centers in a more stable and clean way. It may seem like science fiction, but the future could go in this direction. In addition to the energy issue, there is the theme of security. As AI becomes more powerful, the risks of cyber attacks and improper use of data also increase. Protecting sensitive information will be a priority for governments, companies, and users, who will have to find the right balance between innovation and data protection. As said by an expert, 'The future of AI is not just about technology, but also about responsibility and sustainability.'

**Malicious Apps Steal Images and Access Sensitive Info on iPhones and Androids**
A report by PhoneArena revealed that malicious apps have been discovered in the iOS App Store that can steal images and access sensitive information on iPhones. The apps, part of a campaign called SparkCat, target both Android and iPhone users through official and unofficial channels. Over 242,000 times, these malicious apps were downloaded from Google Play by Android users. Although the exact number of iPhone users affected is unknown, the fact that these apps made it to the App Store is notable, as no image-stealing apps have been found before. The malicious apps use an additional component, a machine learning-based OCR tool from Google's ML Kit, to read text from images and send them to cybercriminals responsible for the malware. The apps search for cryptocurrency wallet recovery phrases and can also identify other important information in images, such as messages or passwords captured in screenshots. Some of the affected apps include food delivery app ComeCome, chatbot app ChatAi, and messaging apps WeTink and AnyGPT, which are still available on Google Play and the App Store. According to the report, the malware has been active since March 2024, and it was difficult to identify the affected apps as they did not necessarily behave suspiciously and used the intended functionality to run the malware without additional permissions. The campaign primarily targets Android and iPhone users in Europe and Asia. If you have any of the mentioned apps on your phone, make sure to delete them, and to keep your device safe from such malware, avoid saving screenshots containing sensitive information in your phone's gallery.

**Cold, Late, Overpriced: The Truth About Game Day Food Delivery**
According to Chatmeter's 2025 Restaurant Delivery & Reputation report, 36% of Americans plan to order food for the Big Game on February 9, with 37% intending to spend more than they did in 2024. However, many consumers are opting for pick-up or home-cooked meals due to ongoing frustrations with the delivery experience, including high fees, frequent delivery delays, incorrect orders, and subpar customer service. John Mazur, CEO of Chatmeter, said, 'Americans love the convenience of delivery, but restaurants that fully hand over the experience to third-party apps without a strategic approach put their reputation at risk.' The report highlights that 55% of consumers cited high fees as the top reason for skipping food delivery, followed by long estimated wait times (43%), concerns about cold food (41%), and higher delivery menu prices compared to in-restaurant dining (39%). Despite these frustrations, many Americans still see food delivery as an essential part of their Big Game plans, with 42% of respondents preferring to focus on watching the game or socialising rather than preparing food.

**AI-Powered Services for 2025: A Guide**
Several AI-powered services are available for use in 2025, including ChatGPT, Custom GPT's, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, Suno, ElevenLabs, Midjourney, Photoshop Firefly, and Runway. ChatGPT is a language assistant that can generate text responses and help with idea formulation. Custom GPT's are specialized bots that can be trained on specific data or constrained to specific tasks. Gemini is a Google-integrated language assistant that can help with office tasks and content creation. GitHub Copilot is a code completion tool that can suggest code fragments based on comments and context. Suno is a music generation service that can create melodies and vocal parts. ElevenLabs is a speech synthesis service that can convert text to speech with high-quality results. Midjourney is a visual content generation service that can create images based on text descriptions. Photoshop Firefly is a neural network-based tool that can synthesize or modify image elements with text commands. Runway is a video editing and post-production service that can correct video clips, change backgrounds, and apply effects. Grammarly is a writing assistant that can analyze grammar, syntax, and style. These services offer various pricing plans, including free versions and paid subscriptions.

**App Store: Malware uses screenshots to steal cryptocurrencies**
Kaspersky, a cybersecurity software company, has discovered a malware campaign called 'SparkCat' that uses the technology OCR to extract text from images, including screenshots, to steal cryptocurrencies. According to Kaspersky, this is the 'first known case' of an app infected with malware that uses OCR technology to extract text from images in the App Store. The malware, which was discovered at the end of 2024, works by requesting access to the user's photo gallery when they try to use the chat support within the infected app. Once granted permission, it uses Google's OCR technology to decipher the text found in the photos, looking for things like screenshots of passwords, encrypted wallets, or recovery phrases. The software then sends all the images it finds to hackers, who can use the information to access wallets and steal cryptocurrencies. Kaspersky says it cannot 'confirm with certainty that the infection was the result of a supply chain attack or a deliberate action by the developers.' Two chat AI apps, WeTink and AnyGPT, and a food delivery app, ComeCome, have been identified as part of the campaign and are still available for download on the App Store. It is not clear when these apps will be removed from the App Store.

**ChatGPT Predicts the Future of Home Technology in 2025**
According to ChatGPT, 2025 will be a 'key year for the massive adoption of intelligent technologies'. The platform predicts that the combination of connectivity, sustainability, and artificial intelligence (AI) will 'revolutionize our homes, making many emerging tools indispensable in the next years'. ChatGPT forecasts that in 2025, virtual assistants will be deeply integrated into daily life, evolving from simple command executors to predictive systems that anticipate needs based on behavior patterns. This will include the management of connected homes, such as turning on lights upon arrival, adjusting the thermostat according to preferences, or even making automatic purchases when supplies run low. The AI also predicts that most homes will have connected appliances that optimize resources and reduce environmental impact, such as refrigerators that control food freshness, washing machines that automatically adjust water consumption, and ovens that can be controlled from a phone. Additionally, intelligent security systems will become a standard, featuring advanced cameras, motion sensors, and digital locks controlled through apps. ChatGPT also expects that health technology will become essential, including smartwatches that monitor vital signs, mirrors that analyze skin, and devices that perform basic diagnoses from home. The platform also predicts a radical change in entertainment, with homes equipped with ultra-high-definition screens (8K), immersive sound systems, and virtual and augmented reality technologies. Finally, advanced energy management systems will become indispensable, allowing for the monitoring and optimization of electricity use, management of solar panels, and storage of energy in domestic batteries, reducing costs and environmental impact. Robots will also become more complex, performing tasks such as deep cleaning, assisting the elderly, and even cooking, equipped with AI that adapts to the dynamics of the home, making them more efficient and personalized.

**Evolution of ChatGPT and AI in 2025: Expert Predictions**
According to experts, in 2025, ChatGPT and other AI generative systems will reach a new level of sophistication by combining deep learning and symbolic reasoning. New use cases, such as medical assistance and ultra-personalized content creation, will emerge and change our habits. However, it will be crucial to preserve critical thinking and ensure optimal transparency on algorithm functioning. Experts also predict that AI will act more like a copilot than a human replacement, with businesses recalibrating their expectations and limiting AI deployment to areas where its impact is most tangible. The question of ethics and regulation will take on greater importance, with the establishment of stricter guidelines for AI development and use. Concerns about data protection and bias management will be at the forefront of debates. The impact on the job market will be significant, with the emergence of new sectors requiring specific skills. The focus will be on continuous training and professional reinsertion to accompany this digital transformation.

**Chatbots Evolve into Autonomous Assistants: What 2025 Holds for AI**
Since the introduction of ChatGPT in late 2022, the landscape of Artificial Intelligence (AI) has undergone a dramatic transformation. Language models like ChatGPT, Perplexity, Gemini, and Claude can answer questions, research online, summarize information, and even create complex texts - all for free. They can also assist in everyday tasks: how to fix a broken bike chain, what ingredients to use in a cheesecake, or how to prepare 'Bleigießen' without lead for New Year's Eve. Chatbots provide answers and help willingly. The leading AI models from various providers have long moved beyond text: they can recognize images (simply upload a photo), understand spoken language, and respond with a natural-sounding voice. During the pre-Christmas period, people (especially children) could talk to Santa Claus for free at ChatGPT. The trend towards 'multimodality' - where a chatbot not only understands and outputs text, but also images, videos, and audio - makes AI tools more versatile than ever. In the new year 2025, experts expect another quantum leap: the increasing competition among providers like OpenAI, Microsoft, Google, Meta, and others will force the operators to offer new features under pressure and become better. AI systems will no longer only react passively, but will also actively act on request. Instead of just providing information, they will complete tasks independently. From booking movie tickets to managing tables - the new agents could drastically simplify everyday life. They will be able to take over tedious everyday tasks. Such AI agents go beyond mere interaction and can complete tasks independently. A typical scenario: the agent searches for the right flight (on request the cheapest, the shortest, only at the favorite airline), books it and informs about the details - all without human intervention. This is not a distant vision, but a feature that will enter everyday applications in 2025. However, the possibilities also raise questions: what data will these assistants collect (more than they do now), and how autonomously can they make decisions? Trust will play a central role, as agents learn their users better with each interaction - they must, otherwise they cannot make sensible decisions. While many basic functions will continue to be offered free of charge or at a low cost, this will not apply to the more powerful options. Providers like OpenAI or Google are increasingly relying on premium models that offer specialized functions and higher capacities - often at a high price. Those who want to use the full range of AI power, for example for analyzing complex data or for advanced automations in business, will not be able to get these services for free. The growing demand for increasingly powerful AI is likely to shift the price structures, making AI a worthwhile investment for both private and professional users.
Original language: de
Publish date: December 30, 2024 05:21 AM
Source:[Westdeutscher Rundfunk](https://www1.wdr.de/nachrichten/ki-chatbots-agenten-100.html)

**Can AI Agents Revolutionize Christmas Shopping in 2025?**
A computer scientist and occasional Christmas shopper wondered if AI could help him with gift purchases. He asked ChatGPT to suggest a personalized gift for his cousin Johnny and deliver it on time, but the friendly chatbot couldn't assist, citing its inability to make purchases or arrange delivery directly. However, new AI products and capabilities have emerged since ChatGPT's launch, promising to simplify everyday tasks. While buying gifts remains beyond their capabilities, except for a few chatbots on websites or apps, experts predict a shift in 2025. AI agents, which can act on behalf of users in the real world, are expected to gain popularity. AI agents can do more than just suggest where to buy a Christmas costume; they can purchase it for the user and deliver it to their doorstep. A team of AI agents can perform tasks in sequence. For example, one can give the task: 'I'm preparing a Christmas dinner. Find my closest friends on Facebook, send them an invitation, and make sure one of them is a chef and brings a turkey.' Agents can accomplish this without user intervention. Limited versions of AI agents already exist, with 51% of those surveyed using them in practice, according to a report by Langchain. Venture capital firms invested $1.8 billion in AI agent projects in 2024, and Deloitte's research predicts that 25% of companies using generative AI will launch AI agents in 2025. However, two main issues remain: trust and contextual understanding. Will users be willing to trust AI agents with their financial information? And can AI agents understand their personal preferences well enough to choose the perfect gift? More is needed than just technology. For now, he will continue to handle his Christmas shopping himself.

Publish date: December 23, 2024 11:11 AM
Source:[nnews.com.ua](https://nnews.com.ua/yak-shtuchnyj-intelekt-mozhe-zminyty-pokupky-na-rizdvo-v-2025-rotsi.html)

While AI systems like ChatGPT can't yet help with Christmas shopping, experts predict that AI agents will be able to take actions on our behalf in the real world by 2025. These agents can already do more than just suggest gift ideas, they can buy and deliver them. However, there are two significant barriers to making AI agents useful: trust and understanding context. Decathlon is revamping its online shop and app to offer a 'digital experience world' that includes DIY workshops, second-hand products, equipment rental, and booking of trainer sessions or ski passes. Meanwhile, Zenfulfillment and Alaiko have merged to create a faster and more reliable delivery service, 'Zenrush', which aims to surpass Amazon's Prime delivery. Flink has partnered with Klarna to offer customers free monthly invoices. Amazon is introducing a new fee for products with high return rates, while Germans are planning to save more in 2025, especially on non-essential items. The EU Commission is investigating TikTok for not properly labeling the campaign of a pro-Russian candidate in the Romanian presidential election. Alibaba is selling its stake in the Intime department store chain to a consortium led by Youngor for $1 billion. Costco's online sales grew by 13% in the last quarter, and the company plans to expand its digital advertising platform. A study found that 45% of British workers would consider switching jobs for more AI tools, and 37% said they couldn't manage their workload without AI. Toom has launched an augmented reality app that allows customers to virtually place Christmas trees in their homes before buying. ChatGPT has expanded its free access to include a powerful web search, and 72% of German youth between 16 and 18 years old consider sustainability when shopping online.
Original language: de
Publish date: December 18, 2024 06:30 AM
Source:[etailment.de](https://etailment.de/news/morning_briefing/morning-briefing-decathlon-alaiko--zenfulfillment-flink--klarna-amazon-tiktok-alibaba--intime-costco-toom-chatgpt-25011)

**10 Unbelievable Predictions by ChatGPT for 2025**
ChatGPT has made 10 unbelievable predictions for 2025, including an AI-powered healthcare revolution, autonomous cities, and the end of passwords. By 2025, AI models will be integrated into healthcare systems, diagnosing diseases and creating personalized treatment plans. Major cities will be transformed into fully autonomous hubs, with AI managing traffic systems and energy distribution. Biometric security will replace passwords, and digital companions will be able to understand human emotions deeply. Fully immersive virtual offices will become commonplace, and AI tutors will customize learning experiences for each student. Renewable energy sources will meet global energy demands with minimal environmental impact, and space travel will become mainstream. Real-time translation devices will make language barriers a thing of the past, and humans might upload memories or augment their cognitive abilities with AI, leading to a blurring of lines between man and machine.
Original language: en
Publish date: December 12, 2024 07:00 AM
Source:[moneycontrol.com](https://www.moneycontrol.com/education/10-unbelievable-predictions-by-chatgpt-for-2025-visual-story-2683008.html)
